Award.AwardTitle: NCS-FO: Sensory-Motor Integration via Recording and Stimulating Arm Nerves

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most ongoing research to develop advanced hand and arm prostheses that allow an individual with amputation to perform highly dexterous movements and to sense features of objects in the world has separated the performance of movements from the sensing of objects. However, in individuals with normal ability, sensory and motor information are integrated. This project's goal is to create movement and sensation abilities in individuals with amputation that are more similar to that in normally enabled individuals. In particular, the goal is to understand how to best utilize all of the available motor and sensory information in the design of accurate neural controllers for future generations of forearm prostheses. This integrated approach to creating sensory percepts and interpreting motor intent will recreate the natural, minimally monitored use of an artificial hand in volunteers as they interact with their world. Successful completion of the proposed work will begin the process of creating a prosthetic hand that passes the 'Turing Test,' where the user perceives little difference between the artificial hand and their amputated biological hand.

The program of research involves implanting neural interfaces (for both stimulating and recording) in the major arm nerves of human volunteers and investigating use of these interfaces while the volunteers interact with a virtual world. In particular, the project has the goals of (a) identifying components in peripheral nerve signals that correlate with errors between the intended movement and the actual movement of the prosthetic arm; (b) developing accurate encoders and stimulation systems that provide punctate, naturalistic, multimodal, and graded sensory percepts; and (c) developing, characterizing, and evaluating advanced decoders that estimate movement intent from a combination of peripheral nerve signals and sensory information from the prosthesis. This third goal, an advanced decoder, will be evaluated with scenarios that provide a clear measure of performance and that represent activities of daily living. The integration of sensory percepts and motor intent is expected to create a natural, minimally monitored use of a prosthetic hand in order to interact more effectively with the world.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Loss of one’s hand is an extremely traumatic event, as every day ones wakes up and is reminded of what they have lost. Despite the loss, much of the nerve and muscle circuitry remains, which allows one to move the hand they no longer have and to feel the sensations from the hand they no longer have. Modern prostheses are enabled with the ability to replicate much of the motion of the hand and with electronic sensors that can detect when the prosthetic hand touches surfaces, and this project used both nerve and muscle interfaces to connect such a prosthetic to the user’s muscles and nerves.

The major outcomes of this research are the following:  (1) New algorithms to provide more naturalistic translation from the prosthetic’s electronic sensors to the nerves, and thus provide naturalistic sensory feedback were developed in this research. (2) This research resulted in the development of advanced machine learning algorithms to interpret a person’s volitional movement intent from muscle and nerve signals. These algorithms provided higher accuracy as well as more natural prosthetic movements than previously possible. (3) Integrating prosthetic controllers equipped with the advanced movement intent decoder algorithms with sensory feedback techniques was showed to result in better prosthetic performance than the movement intend decoder alone. (4) The research produced a shared controller framework for highly-enabled prostheses. Such systems integrate the control of prosthetic movement with a supervisory system that interprets the intended goal of the movement to provide better results than the component systems individually.

Further, the results of this research have shown that use of highly enabled prosthetics can create desirable secondary effects beyond just increasing the quality of life of the user. Such effects include incorporation of the prosthetic into the user’s body image and reduction of phantom pain.

It is anticipated that this work will pave the way for the development of neural prosthetic devices that act and feel like natural arms. This will bring about significant enhancement in the capabilities for people who have lost their arms as well as increased satisfaction and a sense of wellness in such people.

This work furthered the training and development of the multiple undergraduate students, multiple graduate students, and a post-doctoral fellow working on this project. Over the grant’s duration, 3 undergraduate students, 11 graduate students, and 1 post-doctoral fellow were trained on problems related to this grant. Three additional post-doctoral fellows have participated in activities related to the project but were not paid from the project.


Last Modified: 10/14/2019
Modified by: David J Warren

(2) This research resulted in the development of advanced machine learning algorithms to interpret a person?s volitional movement intent from muscle and nerve signals. These algorithms provided higher accuracy as well as more natural prosthetic movements than previously possible.
